content.question:
The distribution of weight of a small watermelon is known to have a mean of <math alttext="5 pounds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>pounds</mtext></math> and a standard deviation of <math alttext="1.2 pounds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.2</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>pounds</mtext></math>. Six small watermelons fit in a crate, and the crate weighs exactly <math alttext="1 pound" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>pound</mtext></math>.
Assuming the weights of small watermelons are independent, what is the standard deviation of the total weight of a random sample of <math alttext="6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn></math> small watermelons and the crate?

choices.label: <math alttext="the square root of, 6 squared, times open parenthesis, 1.2, close parenthesis, squared, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msqrt><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.2</mn><msup><mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></math>

<math alttext="1 plus the square root of, 6 squared, times open parenthesis, 1.2, close parenthesis, squared, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msqrt><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.2</mn><msup><mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="1 plus 6 squared, times open parenthesis, 1.2, close parenthesis, squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.2</mn><msup><mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the square root of, 6 times open parenthesis, 1.2, close parenthesis, squared, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mn>6</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.2</mn><msup><mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="1 plus the square root of, 6 times open parenthesis, 1.2, close parenthesis, squared, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msqrt><mrow><mn>6</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.2</mn><msup><mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="the square root of, 6 times open parenthesis, 1.2, close parenthesis, squared, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mn>6</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.2</mn><msup><mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 4: Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions

skill.text: Skill 3.B: Determine parameters for probability distributions.
